Trial_Design.evidence: Sixty patients undergoing appendectomy operations were randomized in 3 groups.

Participants.evidence: This study was conducted in Shahid Mohamadi Hospital.

Intervention.evidence: Group A received intravenous Dexmedetomidine bolus (1 μg/kg) and infusion (0.5 μg/kg/h). Group B received slow intravenous bolus ketorolac 30 mg. Group C was the control group.

Objective.evidence: The primary objective was to test the hypothesis that the preemptive/preventive effect of Dexmedetomidine would attenuate the post-operative pain more effectively compared to ketorolac and control groups.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) pain scores recorded at 1, 3, 6, 12 and 24 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Sixty patients undergoing appendectomy operations were randomized in 3 groups.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty patients undergoing appendectomy operations were randomized in 3 groups.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the Dexmedetomidine group the mean ± SD pain VAS scores 1.15 ± 1.98 and 0.95 ± 1.76 were significantly lower at 12 and 24 hours after operation (P = 0.004 and P = 0.003) compared to the other two (ketorolac and control) groups.
